habitat_description:
Generally, this species prefers fast-flowing streams in riparian, subalpine, or coastal habitats (Bengtson 1966, Kuchel 1977, Wallen 1987, Cassirer and Groves 1991, 1994). Two distinct habitats used for breeding: coastal estuarine sites (Dzinbal 1982, Crowley 1994) and inland watersheds (Kuchel 1977, Wallen 1987, Breault and Savard 1991, Cassirer and Groves 1991, Smith 1996a, 1996b, 1996c, Bruner 1997, Hunt 1998). In Labrador, streams used tend to be narrower, warmer, and less acidic, and have larger substrates, steeper banks, and greater amounts of vegetative cover along streambanks and islands than unused streams (Rodway 1998)(quoted directly from Robertson and Goudie 1999).
In winter, this species uses coastal rocky shorelines (Savard 1988), and shallow (<10 m deep) intertidal and subtidal rocky benches and cobble beaches (quoted directly from Robertson and Goudie 1999).

Southwest:
Breeding habitat is fast-flowing streams in riparian, sub-alpine or coastal habitats; inland nests are along banks or near gravel bars (Robertson and Goudie 1999). This species requires undisturbed, low gradient mountain streams with dense shrubby riparian areas (NatureServe). In these habitats the Harlequin duck prefers areas with log jams and overhanging vegetation for cover and loafing (NatureServe). Nesting usually occurs in a hollow under cover of shrubs or in rock crevices or cavities (NatureServe). This species has a strong fidelity to nesting sites in successive years (NatureServe). Streams with low acidity also preferred in Idaho (Cassirer and Groves 1994). In British Columbia and Alberta, breeding pairs use lakes, offshore islands, and mainland coasts (Campbell et al. 1990, Breault and Savard 1991, Hunt 1998). May nest up-stream of areas where pairs normally are seen (Cassirer and Groves 1992, MacCallum and Bugera 1998)(quoted directly from Robertson and Goudie 1999).
Winter habitat includes coastal rocky shorelines (Savard 1988). Distributed over shallow (<10 m deep) intertidal and subtidal rocky benches and cobble beaches. In Washington, found in only 1.1 m ± 1.1 SD of water, usually over eelgrass (Zostera spp.) and kelp communities (Hirsch 1980). Occasionally seen on water over sandy beaches or mudflats (Savard 1988a, Patten et al. 1998)(quoted directly from Robertson and Goudie 1999).

Northeast:
Found at exposed headlands and over subtidal ledges (Palmer 1949, G. Mittelhauser pers. comm.). Winter range is determined largely by availability of suitable prey. High densities of Harlequin Ducks sometimes found over mussel (Mytilus adulis) beds (Patten et al. 1998). Not deterred by rough seas (Palmer 1949). May use boulders, rocks, and shorelines as haul-outs. Often remains close to shoreline. Roosts on open water farther (>1 km) from shore at night (Fleischner 1983, (Savard 1988)(quoted directly from Robertson and Goudie 1999).
